Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: A fellow activist is live-streaming from a small demonstration right now and has asked for more people to show up if they are free.
Story: The shrill site alarm jolts me from my focus, and I drop my tools, heart pounding. Protocol is clear: stop everything, head to the muster point, no exceptions. My foreman’s voice echoes in my head—“We’re a team. Safety first, always.” I fall in line with the others, boots crunching gravel, but my phone buzzes in my pocket. A message flashes from Maya, my friend and fellow activist: “We need more people at the protest. Can you come? It’s getting tense.” I glance at the live stream—familiar faces, signs raised, voices urgent. I know how much it matters, how every body counts. But here, on site, I’m counted on too. If I slip away, I let my crew down, risk my job, maybe even my safety. If I stay, I let my cause down, miss a moment that could matter. My hands tremble as I weigh the hard hat on my head against the conviction in my chest, torn between two worlds that both demand all of me.
